title: Booms, busts, and Seattle’s place in the AI era, with Jeff Shulman of the UW Foster School
description: UW professor Jeff Shulman joins the GeekWire Podcast to discuss Seattle’s role in the AI era, the city’s startup challenges, and the push to bring back the Sonics.
content:
What’s at stake for Seattle in times of dramatic change?

University of Washington Foster School of Business marketing professor Jeff Shulman has spent years studying that question, as host of the Seattle Growth Podcast, director of the Product Management Center, and a civic voice on issues ranging from housing affordability to the campaign to bring back the Sonics.

On this episode of the GeekWire Podcast, Shulman joins us to talk about Seattle’s place in the global AI boom, why the city has struggled to produce superstar startups, what AI means for marketing and education, and how civic identity, tech, business, and sports have fueled the region in the past.

Shulman reflects on Seattle’s history of tech booms, noting that past eras led by Boeing, Microsoft, and Amazon created powerful local ecosystems and virtuous cycles that attracted talent and spurred innovation.

It happened most recently with the rise of the cloud, led by Amazon Web Services.

But the dynamic isn’t repeating itself in the current AI wave, with the industry’s center of gravity forming in the Bay Area instead. Two GeekWire stories this week underscored the problem: one highlighting Seattle’s absence from the top AI startup funding rounds, the other examining the regulatory hurdles preventing robotaxis in the region.

“We still have Amazon and Microsoft, but we have not become the Al capital of the world like we should have,” Shulman said. “We’re not seeing that virtuous cycle with Al yet, and it’s a missed opportunity.”
• Seattle is a global AI hub — but where are the superstar startups?
• Despite status as a global tech hub, Seattle passengers still can’t hail a driverless ride
• Seattle Now Podcast: Casual Friday with Todd Bishop and Jeff Shulman

Also check out the Seattle Growth Podcast and “On the Brink” documentary.

Subscribe to GeekWire in Apple Podcasts, Spotify, or wherever you listen.
summary: University of Washington Foster School of Business marketing professor Jeff Shulman discusses the role of Seattle in the AI era, where the city has struggled to produce superstar startups. He also discusses the impact of AI on marketing and education, and how civic identity, tech, business, and sports have fueled the region in the past. Despite being a global tech hub, Seattle passengers still can't hail a driverless ride. Shuleman also commented on the absence of top AI startup funding rounds and regulatory hurdles preventing robotaxis in the region.
shortSummary: Jeff Shulman, a UW Foster School of Business professor, discusses Seattle’s past tech booms and current challenges in producing superstar AI startups, emphasizing the importance of local identity and collaboration.

scraped_sources.text:
Ken Griffey Jr. is well-known for being one of the most iconic figures in Seattle sports history. Griffey has maintained a strong connection with the Emerald City, from his early days electrifying crowds at the Kingdome of his Hall of Fame career that propelled the Mariners to national fame.
Currently, he has expressed an interest in stepping into a new role—this time outside of the field and into the ownership ranks—as a member of a group that aims to bring the NBA back to Seattle. Griffey expressed his willingness to help restore the Seattle Supersonics to their rightful place in the city’s sports landscape in an interview with LandonBuford.com.
Seattle’s Longing for the Sonics
Seattle’s identity has been shaped by the SuperSonics for more than 40 years, winning the NBA championship in 1979 and producing stars like Gary Payton, Shawn Kemp, Ray Allen, and Kevin Durant. In 2008, the franchise controversially moved to Oklahoma City, leaving a hole that remains unfilled.
The Sonics’ demise remains a bittersweet moment for many fans, and the city’s pursuit of an NBA return is a common cause throughout the Pacific Northwest. Griffey’s desire to own something demonstrates the extent of the Sonics’ absence.
Griffey is a passionate sports fan who comprehends how a professional franchise affects a city’s culture and economy beyond his Hall of Fame baseball career. His voice is significant because of his legendary status in Seattle, as well as his business acumen and growing involvement in sports ownership circles.
Griffey’s Transition Beyond Baseball
Griffey has recently ventured into various off-field activities, including joining the Mariners’ ownership group in 2021. His move was a surprise as he became the first former player to have a stake in the franchise. If he decides to pursue NBA ownership, that experience could be a blueprint for what his role would look like.
His investment in the Mariners was a reflection of his strong commitment to the city and its sports heritage, and the idea of expanding that impact to basketball is a natural development. Seattle’s sports fan base is strong for many different sports, like the Seahawks in the NFL, the Storm in the WNBA, or the Kraken in the NHL. The Sonics’ return would reinforce Seattle’s reputation as one of America’s most dynamic sports cities.
The Road to the NBA’s Return
Griffey’s remarks will definitely exhilarate fans, but the process of introducing the Sonics is intricate. Seattle will be a top contender when the NBA decides to expand, but Commissioner Adam Silver has acknowledged it as a top contender. Seattle’s support for another professional basketball franchise can be seen in the recent success of Climate Pledge Arena, which currently hosts the NHL’s Kraken and the WNBA’s Storm.
For many years, there has been talk of potential ownership groups, and prominent figures such as Chris Hansen and Jeff Bezos have been suggested as potential backers. The inclusion of Griffey’s name results in a unique, sentimental and symbolic value. The idea of a loved athlete leading the charge in reviving the Sonics is a powerful emotional dimension for Seattle sports fans.
A Symbol of Legacy and Hope
Ken Griffey Jr. has always been more than just a ballplayer to Seattle. During his time, the city began to define itself on the national sports stage. Griffey’s desire to play a role in the Sonics’ rebirth places him again at the heart of Seattle’s sports story.
Griffey’s participation is not only ownership for fans who have been waiting for their team to return for almost two decades; it is also proof of authenticity and dedication to the city’s legacy. Griffey being included in the ownership group would make it significantly for the Sonics to return in the event of NBA expansion.
Seattle’s tale of loss and longing would ultimately culminate in one of restoration and triumph. Griffey stated that Seattle is lacking something. If he has anything to do with it, the missing piece, the green and gold of the Seattle SuperSonics, could one day come back to its proper place.

Casual Friday with Todd Bishop and Jeff Shulman
Kroger announced upcoming closures to 4 Fred Meyers in the Seattle area.
Washington’s only hybrid electric ferry isn’t working.
And people are acting up in public.
UW Professor Jeff Shulman and Geekwire Co-Founder Todd Bishop are here to break down the week.

argos_summary: Seattle has long been a tech powerhouse thanks to Boeing, Microsoft, and Amazon, but it has struggled to become a leading AI hub, with Jeff Shulman noting a lack of AI startup funding and regulatory hurdles such as robotaxi bans that prevent the virtuous cycle seen in the Bay Area. Meanwhile, former baseball star Ken Griffey Jr. is exploring ownership to help bring back the Seattle SuperSonics, reflecting the city’s deep longing for a return to its basketball legacy. The podcast and related coverage highlight Seattle’s evolving civic identity, tech ecosystem, and sports aspirations.
